title: The hottest of hot spaces at the peakiest of market peaks
text:
One fine for overly aggressive culture to start: 3G-backed Kraft Heinz has agreed to pay $62m after being charged with false accounting over a period of three years in which it is alleged the food company improperly claimed more than $200m worth of cost savings. Read the story here and the SEC complaint here.

The newest gravy train in private capital: private capital management

We've written in DD about the new batch of private equity firms — from Bridgepoint to TPG — which have either recently made debuts, or are planning to do so, on the public markets. 

Deals are being struck everywhere at record pace, dry powder is seemingly endless and public investors are finally embracing the sticky fees charged by buyout groups.

Policymakers, who have historically been a major threat to the rich rewards of the industry, seem to be easily disarmed through lobbying efforts or the right job offer.

Now it looks like another part of the industry is starting to gain momentum. Petershill Partners, a unit of Goldman Sachs which focuses on buying stakes in private equity firms, is looking to become the second such business to go public this year.

The first came in the form of a controversial three-way merger, which closed in May when Dyal Capital combined with credit fund Owl Rock and went public through a deal with a Spac to create a new group called Blue Owl. 

With Petershill gearing up to raise $750m in London, it's reasonable to ask if either Blackstone's Strategic Capital Holdings or AlpInvest Partners will be the next in line.

Why do such firms exist in the first place?

Private equity groups receive hefty management fees from the pension funds and other investors whose money they manage. That is enormously valuable — but not very liquid. 

Businesses like Dyal and Petershill emerged to provide that liquidity. They raise external cash, often from pension funds, with which to buy out the stakes, essentially buying a share of the management fees — and sometimes the carried interest too. 

Some told pension funds that they would eventually return their cash by selling the stakes either privately or publicly. This summer's IPO of Bridgepoint, in which Dyal had bought a stake, was a case in point. 

Now, the very businesses that were created to provide liquidity for private fund partners are themselves looking for liquidity from public market investors. Petershill owns minority stakes in 19 alternative asset companies with a combined $187bn of assets under management. 

Our former colleague Jonathan Ford looked at the complexities of these new private equity firms in a column last year: “How soon before this next layer of middlemen — the bosses of Dyal and Petershill — are themselves billionaires?” he wrote.

Listing these general partners stake funds extends what was already a complicated chain of financialisation one step further. 

It means that the ability to benefit from pension funds' management fees has now been sold on from private equity groups to financial intermediaries, and then on again to stock market investors. If pension funds started to push back against paying the hefty fees, there could be quite a chain reaction. 

As one buyout boss told Lex: private capital management is “the hottest of hot spaces at the peakiest of market peaks”. DD wonders how long it will last.

Blood, sweat and testing: Silicon Valley clings to the Theranos dream

Elizabeth Holmes is on trial for fraud, while her former blood-testing start-up Theranos lingers on Silicon Valley's conscience as a grim consequence of unchecked hype and deep-pocketed investors. 

The company's biggest backers, including Rupert Murdoch, Oracle's Larry Ellison and venture capitalist Tim Draper, had their stakes wiped out as investors lost nearly $1bn from Theranos's collapse.

But even as Holmes faces up to 20 years in prison if convicted, the idea of diagnosing medical issues from tiny samples of blood hasn't lost its allure. Investors have poured $200m into similar companies over the past year alone, DD's Miles Kruppa reports.

Among the undaunted backers is Verily, the life sciences division of Alphabet, which led a $50m round of financing in January for Genalyte, a start-up that promises its proprietary technology can perform multiple rapid tests on small amounts of blood. 

General Catalyst, the venture capital firm chaired by former American Express chief executive Ken Chenault, backed blood-testing start-up Truvian Sciences in a $105m round of funding in February. 

It may seem like a peculiar time, as the media frenzy surrounding Holmes's fall from grace and subsequent trial reaches a fever pitch, for the blood-testing sector to experience a sudden revival.

But start-ups say the demand for reliable Covid testing has renewed interest in the diagnostics market — which could be worth as much as $85bn, according to a recent IPO filing by Cue Health, which has developed a palm-sized device that can conduct a variety of tests.

Some companies said heightened scrutiny resulting from Theranos has forced them to work harder to earn investors' trust, but that it has paid off in the end. “It turned out better than we expected,” said Luc Gervais, whose 1Drop Diagnostics raised more than $4m from investors who had requested more papers and scientific data to back the company's claims.

As blood-testing devices begin to shed their risky reputations, however, one of the most pressing issues at the root of the Theranos controversy continues to sow division.

Holmes has been accused of inaccurately claiming that her company could complete more than 200 tests with just a single drop of blood. “One drop, for a whole host of reasons, doesn't really seem like something you can do,” said Truvian's chief Jeff Hawkins.

Gervais, who aims for 1Drop to do multiple tests on a single drop of blood, disagreed, adding that his company plans to publish data on the accuracy of its tests.

The pressure is on for blood-testing start-ups to show what they're capable of, many of which still lack peer-reviewed studies — something Theranos was criticised for never providing.

The second-largest bankruptcy in Swiss history raises questions for auditors

What do ruby rings, diamond-encrusted watches, Hong Kong penthouses and Brazilian football stars share in common?

Apparently they're all legitimate business expenses.

For years, one Swiss private company stood atop a labyrinthine financial web that accounted for more than 10 per cent of Uzbekistan's GDP. Then, a decade ago, it suddenly collapsed.

Creditors have been trying to trace the assets of Zug-based Zeromax ever since, and prove the company was in fact being run as a vehicle for the personal enrichment of Gulnara Karimova, the daughter of Uzbekistan's former dictator. 

Karimova is now languishing in a Tashkent prison as details of Zeromax's activities — eye-popping expenditure on luxury items and dubious vanity projects — finally come to light. 

An investigation by the FT's Sam Jones in Zurich details some of them for the first time, and the true scale of Zeromax's debts. It is based on dozens of leaked documents and police reports.

At the centre of creditors' current efforts to get their money back are questions for EY, which signed off on Zeromax's accounts. 

EY insists Zeromax's collapse was purely down to an Uzbek power struggle. “Court decisions in Uzbekistan in 2010 caused a de facto expropriation of Zeromax assets and its bankruptcy,” EY told the FT. “This matter is subject to ongoing litigation and EY Switzerland will vigorously defend its position to vexatious claims,” it added. 

Others disagree. Among them is US hedge fund Lionpoint Capital, which is now suing EY in Switzerland for $1bn.

Job moves

  • Goldman Sachs has hired Jassim AlSane from Citigroup as a managing director and co-head of investment banking operations for the Middle East and north Africa. He will be based in Dubai from November, per Bloomberg.

  • Linklaters has hired Francesco De Blasio as partner and practice head for real estate in Italy. He joins from DLA Piper. 

  • Allen & Overy has hired Emanuel Grillo as a partner in its US banking and restructuring group, based in New York, and David Flechner as a partner in its Latin America practice, splitting his time between New York and São Paulo. They join from Baker Botts and Paul Hastings, respectively. 

  • Eversheds Sutherland has hired Jon Gill as a partner in its London corporate practice, where he will focus on M&A, venture capital and private equity in the technology sector. He was previously a partner at TLT.
